The Education Bureau has issued a letter on 4/10 to school principals across the territory as a "warm reminder" on the recently established anti-mask law, further escalating tensions in the society.



The notice urged schools to remind parents and students that under the law, any persons wearing a mask or other objects that could potentially conceal their identity in public assemblies or gatherings would be deemed as illegal and could face potential prosecution. It also stated that the possession of such objects would be incriminating as well, and students should not wear masks or conceal their faces at school or even outside the school. (original: 學生在校內或校外均不應該戴上口罩或以任何方式遮蓋面孔)

Critics have slammed the EDB that the notice would do little to ease social tensions, and also the Bureau is stepping out of bounds in dictating what students could do out of the school setting. They also criticised that the move would spread white terror, something that has proven true as the EDB has further required schools to report the number of students wearing masks to school on the first school day (8/10, tomorrow) after the law has been implemented. The number of students boycotting class or participating in human chain activities outside campus would have to be reported as well. (original: 教育局要求全港中學在新例實施後首個上學日上午11時前，向分區主任提交戴口罩、罷課，或參與校外人鏈活動的人數。) It is unclear that any other personal particulars of the students would be noted down and be reported back to the Bureau, further fuelling claims that the government is spreading white terror in a desperate effort to silence students, who are at the forefront of the anti-ELAB movment.

News sourced from Now.com via Yahoo! News
